p: Sustainable potential habitats were predicted to occur in just three grid cells in the northwestern part of the study area under future climate conditions (Fig. 6a). Our results show that both climatic factors, including cooler temperature, greater snow, and lower summer precipitation, and topographic factors, such as closer to the ridge, leeward, and gentler slope, are positively important for sustaining the potential habitat of L. muta japonica. Potential habitats with GCM-related uncertainty were predicted to occur in the central and northwestern parts of the study area (Fig. 6b). Potential habitats should be considered high-priority candidates for investment in climate adaptation practices.
